23 /*
24  * scoop.c -- This file deals with readahead from caller-supplied
25  * buffers.
26  *
27  * Many functions require a certain minimum amount of input to do their
28  * processing. For example, to calculate a strong checksum of a block
29  * we need at least a block of input.
30  *
31  * Since we put the buffers completely under the control of the caller,
32  * we can't count on ever getting this much data all in one go. We
33  * can't simply wait, because the caller might have a smaller buffer
34  * than we require and so we'll never get it. For the same reason we
35  * must always accept all the data we're given.
36  *
37  * So, stream input data that's required for readahead is put into a
38  * special buffer, from which the caller can then read. It's
39  * essentially like an internal pipe, which on any given read request
40  * may or may not be able to actually supply the data.
41  *
42  * As a future optimization, we might try to take data directly from the
43  * input buffer if there's already enough there.
44  */
45 
46 /*
47  * TODO: We probably know a maximum amount of data that can be scooped
48  * up, so we could just avoid dynamic allocation. However that can't
49  * be fixed at compile time, because when generating a delta it needs
50  * to be large enough to hold one full block. Perhaps we can set it
51  * up when the job is allocated? It would be kind of nice to not do
52  * any memory allocation after startup, as bzlib does this.
53  */
54 
55 
56  /*
57  | To walk on water you've gotta sink
58  | in the ice.
59  | -- Shihad, `The General Electric'.
60  */
61

79 void rs_scoop_input(rs_job_t *job, size_t len)
80 {
81  rs_buffers_t *stream = job->stream;
82  size_t tocopy;
83 
84  assert(len > job->scoop_avail);
85 
86  if (job->scoop_alloc < len) {
87  /* need to allocate a new buffer, too */
88  char *newbuf;
89  int newsize = 2 * len;
90  newbuf = rs_alloc(newsize, "scoop buffer");
91  if (job->scoop_avail)
92  memcpy(newbuf, job->scoop_next, job->scoop_avail);
93  if (job->scoop_buf)
94  free(job->scoop_buf);
95  job->scoop_buf = job->scoop_next = newbuf;
96  rs_trace("resized scoop buffer to " PRINTF_FORMAT_U64 " bytes from " PRINTF_FORMAT_U64 "",
97  PRINTF_CAST_U64(newsize), PRINTF_CAST_U64(job->scoop_alloc));
98  job->scoop_alloc = newsize;
99  } else {
100  /* this buffer size is fine, but move the existing
101  * data down to the front. */
102  memmove(job->scoop_buf, job->scoop_next, job->scoop_avail);
103  job->scoop_next = job->scoop_buf;
104  }
105 
106  /* take as much input as is available, to give up to LEN bytes
107  * in the scoop. */
108  tocopy = len - job->scoop_avail;
109  if (tocopy > stream->avail_in)
110  tocopy = stream->avail_in;
111  assert(tocopy + job->scoop_avail <= job->scoop_alloc);
112 
113  memcpy(job->scoop_next + job->scoop_avail, stream->next_in, tocopy);
114  rs_trace("accepted " PRINTF_FORMAT_U64 " bytes from input to scoop", PRINTF_CAST_U64(tocopy));
115  job->scoop_avail += tocopy;
116  stream->next_in += tocopy;
117  stream->avail_in -= tocopy;
118 }
119 
120 
130 void rs_scoop_advance(rs_job_t *job, size_t len)
131 {
132  rs_buffers_t *stream = job->stream;
133 
134  /* It never makes sense to advance over a mixture of bytes from
135  * the scoop and input, because you couldn't possibly have looked
136  * at them all at the same time. */
137  if (job->scoop_avail) {
138  /* reading from the scoop buffer */
139  rs_trace("advance over %ld bytes from scoop", (long) len);
140  assert(len <= job->scoop_avail);
141  job->scoop_avail -= len;
142  job->scoop_next += len;
143  } else {
144  rs_trace("advance over %ld bytes from input buffer", (long) len);
145  assert(len <= stream->avail_in);
146  stream->avail_in -= len;
147  stream->next_in += len;
148  }
149 }
150 
151 
152 
166 rs_result rs_scoop_readahead(rs_job_t *job, size_t len, void **ptr)
167 {
168  rs_buffers_t *stream = job->stream;
169  rs_job_check(job);
170 
171  if (job->scoop_avail >= len) {
172  /* We have enough data queued to satisfy the request,
173  * so go straight from the scoop buffer. */
174  rs_trace("got " PRINTF_FORMAT_U64 " bytes direct from scoop", PRINTF_CAST_U64(len));
175  *ptr = job->scoop_next;
176  return RS_DONE;
177  } else if (job->scoop_avail) {
178  /* We have some data in the scoop, but not enough to
179  * satisfy the request. */
180  rs_trace("data is present in the scoop and must be used");
181  rs_scoop_input(job, len);
182 
183  if (job->scoop_avail < len) {
184  rs_trace("still have only " PRINTF_FORMAT_U64 " bytes in scoop",
185  PRINTF_CAST_U64(job->scoop_avail));
186  return RS_BLOCKED;
187  } else {
188  rs_trace("scoop now has " PRINTF_FORMAT_U64 " bytes, this is enough",
189  PRINTF_CAST_U64(job->scoop_avail));
190  *ptr = job->scoop_next;
191  return RS_DONE;
192  }
193  } else if (stream->avail_in >= len) {
194  /* There's enough data in the stream's input */
195  *ptr = stream->next_in;
196  rs_trace("got " PRINTF_FORMAT_U64 " bytes from input buffer", PRINTF_CAST_U64(len));
197  return RS_DONE;
198  } else if (stream->avail_in > 0) {
199  /* Nothing was queued before, but we don't have enough
200  * data to satisfy the request. So queue what little
201  * we have, and try again next time. */
202  rs_trace("couldn't satisfy request for " PRINTF_FORMAT_U64 ", scooping " PRINTF_FORMAT_U64 " bytes",
203  PRINTF_CAST_U64(len), PRINTF_CAST_U64(job->scoop_avail));
204  rs_scoop_input(job, len);
205  return RS_BLOCKED;
206  } else if (stream->eof_in) {
207  /* Nothing is queued before, and nothing is in the input
208  * buffer at the moment. */
209  rs_trace("reached end of input stream");
210  return RS_INPUT_ENDED;
211  } else {
212  /* Nothing queued at the moment. */
213  rs_trace("blocked with no data in scoop or input buffer");
214  return RS_BLOCKED;
215  }
216 }
217 
218 
219 
230 rs_result rs_scoop_read(rs_job_t *job, size_t len, void **ptr)
231 {
232  rs_result result;
233 
234  result = rs_scoop_readahead(job, len, ptr);
235  if (result == RS_DONE)
236  rs_scoop_advance(job, len);
237 
238  return result;
239 }

243 /*
244  * Read whatever remains in the input stream, assuming that it runs up
245  * to the end of the file. Set LEN appropriately.
246  */
247 rs_result rs_scoop_read_rest(rs_job_t *job, size_t *len, void **ptr)
248 {
249  rs_buffers_t *stream = job->stream;
250 
251  *len = job->scoop_avail + stream->avail_in;
252 
253  return rs_scoop_read(job, *len, ptr);
254 }
255

257 
262 size_t rs_scoop_total_avail(rs_job_t *job)
263 {
264  return job->scoop_avail + job->stream->avail_in;
265 }
